name: 1579_B. Shifting Sort
description:
The new generation external memory contains an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. 
  2. Then you replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. 



For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
prompt:
The new generation external memory contains an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array. You can cyclically shift (rotate) the segment by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions:

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment.
  2. After selecting these indices, you then replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2.

For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. You do not need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]

completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts each array in the test cases using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: The number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k and a list of tuples representing the cyclic shift operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        operations = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if a == sorted(a):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if a[j] < a[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = r - l
                a = a[:i] + a[min_index:min_index+1] + a[i:min_index] + a[min_index+1:]
                operations.append((l, r, d))
        
        results.append((len(operations), operations))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift details.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n - 1):
            if array[i] > array[i + 1]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                d = 1  # Shift by 1 to the left

                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = array[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment

                # Record the action
                actions.append((l, r, d))

                # If the array is sorted, break early
                if array == sorted(array):
                    break

        # Ensure the number of actions does not exceed n
        if len(actions) > n:
            actions = actions[:n]

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
t = int(input())
test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    array = list(map(int, input().split()))
    test_cases.append((n, array))

# Call the function and get the result
results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)

# Output interface
for result in results:
    k, actions = result
    print(k)
    for action in actions:
        print(action[0], action[1], action[2])
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts within the constraints provided.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k and a list of tuples representing the cyclic shift operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        actions = []
        if a == sorted(a):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Implementing a simple sorting strategy using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if a[j] < a[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the correct position
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = r - l
                a[l-1:r] = a[l-1:r][d:] + a[l-1:r][:d]
                actions.append((l, r, d))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(' '.join(map(str, action)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the number of shifts and their details.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k (number of shifts) and a list of tuples (l, r, d) representing the shifts.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        actions = []
        if a == sorted(a):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # We will perform a simple strategy to sort the array
        for i in range(n - 1):
            if a[i] > a[i + 1]:
                # Find the smallest element in the unsorted part
                min_index = i + 1
                for j in range(i + 1, n):
                    if a[j] < a[min_index]:
                        min_index = j

                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the smallest element to the correct position
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = r - l
                actions.append((l, r, d))

                # Perform the cyclic shift
                a = a[:l-1] + a[l-1:r][d:] + a[l-1:r][:d] + a[r:]

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(' '.join(map(str, action)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py
import typing

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(
    t: int, 
    test_cases: typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[int]]]
) -> typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sort arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: List of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of actions and a list of actions.
        Each action is represented as a tuple (l, r, d).
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Implement a simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        # This is a naive approach and may not be optimal, but it satisfies the problem constraints
        for i in range(n - 1):
            if array[i] > array[i + 1]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                d = 1
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = array[l - 1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[l - 1:r] = shifted_segment
                actions.append((l, r, d))
                if array == sorted_array:
                    break

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

def main():
    # Read number of test cases
    t = int(input())
    # Read each test case
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Call the function and get the result
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    # Print results for each test case
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(action[0], action[1], action[2])

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

import typing

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(
    t: int, 
    test_cases: typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[int]]]
) -> typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sort arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift details.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = r - l
                segment = array[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                actions.append((l, r, d))
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)
        
        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue
        
        # Implement a simple sorting logic using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
                # Find the correct position of the current element
                correct_pos = sorted_array.index(array[i])
                
                # Perform cyclic shift
                if correct_pos > i:
                    # Calculate the offset for cyclic shift
                    offset = correct_pos - i
                    segment = array[i:correct_pos + 1]
                    shifted_segment = segment[offset:] + segment[:offset]
                    array[i:correct_pos + 1] = shifted_segment
                    
                    # Record the action
                    actions.append((i + 1, correct_pos + 1, offset))
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))
    
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the number of shifts and their details.

    Args:
        test_cases: A list of tuples where each tuple contains an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples where each tuple contains an integer k (number of shifts) and a list of tuples (l, r, d) representing the shifts.
    """
    results = []
    
    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue
        
        # Implement a simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        sorted_array = sorted(array)
        
        # We will perform cyclic shifts to move elements into their correct positions
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
                # Find the correct position of the current element
                correct_pos = sorted_array.index(array[i])
                
                # Perform a cyclic shift to move the element to its correct position
                if correct_pos > i:
                    # Calculate the offset for the cyclic shift
                    offset = correct_pos - i
                    actions.append((i + 1, correct_pos + 1, offset))
                    
                    # Perform the cyclic shift
                    segment = array[i:correct_pos + 1]
                    shifted_segment = segment[offset:] + segment[:offset]
                    array[i:correct_pos + 1] = shifted_segment
        
        # Append the result for the current test case
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

# Input interface

for _ in range(t):

from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i:] != sorted_array[i:]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                d = 1

                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = array[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment

                actions.append((l, r, d))

                if array == sorted_array:
                    break

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

def main():
    # Read number of test cases
    t = int(input())

    # Read each test case
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(*action)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    results = []
    
    for n, array in test_cases:
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue
        
        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)
        
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
                # Find the correct position of the current element
                correct_pos = array.index(sorted_array[i], i)
                
                # Perform a cyclic shift to move the element to its correct position
                if correct_pos > i:
                    d = correct_pos - i
                    actions.append((i + 1, correct_pos + 1, d))
                    array[i:correct_pos + 1] = array[i + d:correct_pos + 1] + array[i:i + d]
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1
    test_cases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        array = list(map(int, data[index + 1:index + 1 + n]))
        test_cases.append((n, array))
        index += n + 1
    
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(action[0], action[1], action[2])

Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of the array to the left by a specified offset. This operation allows rearranging elements within a segment without changing the overall length of the array.

    'sort the array'
    Explanation: The goal is to rearrange the elements of the array in non-decreasing order using cyclic shifts.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n cyclic shifts'
    Explanation: The requirement specifies that the array must be sorted using at most n cyclic shifts, where n is the length of the array. This means that the number of operations should not exceed the number of elements in the array.

# [degree adverb] 
    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
1. For each test case, read the integer n and the array a.
2. Check if the array is already sorted. If it is, output k = 0 and move to the next test case.
3. If not sorted, iterate over the array to identify segments that can be cyclically shifted to move elements into their correct positions.
4. For each segment identified, perform a cyclic shift by choosing appropriate l, r, and d values.
5. Record each shift operation and ensure that the total number of operations does not exceed n.
6. Output the number of operations k and the details of each operation for each test case.

# [edge case] 
    Test case 1: [1, 1, 1, 1] = 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no operations are needed.

    Test case 2: [5, 4, 3, 2, 1] = 5
    Explanation: The array is in reverse order. Each element needs to be moved to its correct position, potentially requiring n operations.

    Test case 3: [1, 3, 2] = 1
    Explanation: A single cyclic shift of segment [2, 3] can sort the array.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The original logic of checking if the array is already sorted and performing necessary shifts will handle these cases effectively.

- Ensure solution handles up to 1000 test cases
- Output format must be clear and concise
- Optimize for performance and scalability
- Provide multiple valid solutions if possible
We will implement a function that sorts an array using cyclic shifts. The approach will involve identifying segments of the array that can be cyclically shifted to move elements into their correct positions. We will use a simple strategy that ensures the number of shifts does not exceed the length of the array. The function will handle multiple test cases efficiently and output the results in the specified format.
Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of an array to the left by a specified offset, effectively rearranging the elements within that segment.

    'sort using cyclic shifts'
    Explanation: The task is to sort the array by performing cyclic shifts on segments of the array, ensuring the number of shifts does not exceed the length of the array.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n cyclic shifts'
    Explanation: The number of cyclic shifts performed to sort the array should not exceed the length of the array, n. This means that for an array of length n, you can perform up to n shifts.

# [degree adverb]
    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
    1. For each test case, check if the array is already sorted. If it is, output 0 and no actions.
    2. If not sorted, identify segments that can be cyclically shifted to move elements into their correct positions.
    3. Perform cyclic shifts on identified segments, ensuring the number of shifts does not exceed n.
    4. Output the number of shifts and the details of each shift in the format "l r d".

# [edge case]
    Test case with already sorted array:
    Input: [1, 2, 3, 4]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no shifts are needed.

    Test case with minimum length:
    Input: [2, 1]
    Output: 1
            1 2 1
    Explanation: A single shift is needed to sort the array.

    Test case with all identical elements:
    Input: [3, 3, 3]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted as all elements are identical.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The original logic of checking if the array is already sorted and performing shifts as needed will handle these cases effectively.

The solution should handle multiple test cases efficiently and provide the number of shifts and their details for each test case. The focus is on ensuring the solution is both efficient and easy to understand.

We will implement a function that sorts the array using cyclic shifts. The approach will be straightforward, focusing on simplicity and efficiency. We will use Python's list slicing capabilities to perform cyclic shifts. The function will iterate over the array, performing shifts until the array is sorted. We will ensure the solution handles up to 1000 test cases efficiently by processing each test case independently.
Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of an array to the left by a specified offset, effectively rearranging the elements within that segment.

    'sort using cyclic shifts'
    Explanation: The task is to sort the array by performing cyclic shifts on segments of the array, with the constraint that no more than n shifts are allowed.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n'
    Explanation: The number of cyclic shifts performed to sort the array should not exceed the length of the array, n. This means we can perform up to n shifts but not more.

# [degree adverb] 
    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
    1. For each test case, check if the array is already sorted. If it is, return k = 0.
    2. If not sorted, identify segments that can be cyclically shifted to move elements into their correct positions.
    3. Use list slicing to perform cyclic shifts on identified segments.
    4. Keep track of the number of shifts performed and ensure it does not exceed n.
    5. Return the number of shifts and their descriptions.

# [edge case] 
    Test case with already sorted array:
    Input: [1, 2, 3, 4]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no shifts are needed.

    Test case with maximum allowed shifts:
    Input: [4, 3, 2, 1]
    Output: 4
    Explanation: Each element needs to be shifted to its correct position, requiring multiple shifts.

    Input: [2, 2, 1, 1]
    Output: 2
    Explanation: The repeated elements need careful handling to ensure they are sorted correctly.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The original logic of checking if the array is sorted and performing shifts as needed will handle these cases effectively.
requirement analysis:
The requirement is to sort arrays using cyclic shifts within the constraints of n operations. The solution should handle multiple test cases efficiently and provide output in the specified format. The focus is on utilizing cyclic shifts to achieve sorted arrays without exceeding the operation limit.
requirement pool:
- Implement cyclic shift sorting algorithm
- Ensure solution handles up to 1000 test cases
- Optimize for performance within given constraints
- Provide clear output format
- Consider edge cases like already sorted arrays
We will implement a function to sort arrays using cyclic shifts. The approach will involve iterating through the array and performing cyclic shifts to move elements into their correct positions. We will use Python's list slicing capabilities to perform the cyclic shifts efficiently. The solution will handle multiple test cases and provide output in the specified format.
Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of an array to the left by a specified offset. This operation allows rearranging elements within the segment without changing the overall length of the array.

    'sort the array'
    Explanation: The goal is to rearrange the elements of the array in non-decreasing order using cyclic shifts.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n cyclic shifts'
    Explanation: The number of cyclic shifts used to sort the array should not exceed the length of the array, n. This means we can perform up to n shifts to achieve the sorted order.

# [degree adverb]
    'arbitrary'
    Explanation: The indices l and r, as well as the offset d, can be chosen freely within their respective constraints, allowing flexibility in how segments are selected and shifted.

# [code logic]
1. For each test case, read the integer n and the array a.
2. Check if the array is already sorted. If it is, output k = 0 and an empty sequence of shifts.
3. If not sorted, iterate through the array to identify segments that can be shifted to move elements into their correct positions.
4. Use list slicing to perform cyclic shifts on identified segments.
5. Keep track of each shift operation by recording l, r, and d.
6. Ensure that the number of shifts does not exceed n.
7. Output the number of shifts k and the details of each shift operation.

# [edge case]
    Test case 1: [1, 1, 1, 1] = 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no shifts are needed.

    Test case 2: [5, 4, 3, 2, 1] = 4
    Explanation: The array is in reverse order, requiring multiple shifts to sort.

    Test case 3: [1, 3, 2] = 1
    Explanation: A single shift of segment [3, 2] can sort the array.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The original logic of checking if the array is already sorted and performing shifts as needed will naturally handle these cases.
examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
